results.content: One of the things I like about this course was that Reed spent most of his time explaining what he was doing, and not as much about why.  It forced me to research areas like npm packages, semantic-ui-react, React docs and javascript to find out why they were being used as they were.  This was a great learning experience!  Highly recommend this course!
results.content_html: One of the things I like about this course was that Reed spent most of his time explaining what he was doing, and not as much about why. It forced me to research areas like npm packages, semantic-ui-react, React docs and javascript to find out why they were being used as they were. This was a great learning experience! Highly recommend this course!

results.content:
This course is not for beginners and having a solid understanding of React and Redux is a must.  Firebase knowledge also would help.

I came in cold on Firebase and Reed doesn't take much time to explain the mechanics, especially later on in the course, but I feel through some reviews it'll make more sense...Firebase is not that complex.  

Overall, amazing course.  I felt I improved upon my React, Redux knowledge and was able to mimic some patterns that are clever for messaging, authentication, online status, app coloring and much more.
results.content_html:
This course is not for beginners and having a solid understanding of React and Redux is a must. Firebase knowledge also would help.

I came in cold on Firebase and Reed doesn't take much time to explain the mechanics, especially later on in the course, but I feel through some reviews it'll make more sense...Firebase is not that complex.

Overall, amazing course. I felt I improved upon my React, Redux knowledge and was able to mimic some patterns that are clever for messaging, authentication, online status, app coloring and much more.

results.content: I really enjoyed building a Slack clone as there were enough features to keep it interesting and learn about React.  However, I felt it was more of a "do what I do" course with little explanation on why certain decisions were being made.  I'm also very familiar with Firebase which was great, but I can definitely see someone new to the service getting confused early on.
results.content_html: I really enjoyed building a Slack clone as there were enough features to keep it interesting and learn about React. However, I felt it was more of a "do what I do" course with little explanation on why certain decisions were being made. I'm also very familiar with Firebase which was great, but I can definitely see someone new to the service getting confused early on.

results.content:
Again, great course by Reed. In a short amount of time, you get a lot and in a professional way.
The course is a bit old now so you might want to adjust a few imports such as uuid and maybe replace Class components with hooks etc. but overall, the logic is there and it is an amazing course.

results.content:
I enjoyed the course a lot. I liked the functionality of the app and the way the code is written.
I would say, the only thing this course lacks is making the app fully responsive, even though it can be done by yourself easily using media queries. 
Sometimes instructor goes way too fast through the code and it makes it quite difficult to follow it, you will need to rewind or slow the video down at times.
results.content_html:
I enjoyed the course a lot. I liked the functionality of the app and the way the code is written.
I would say, the only thing this course lacks is making the app fully responsive, even though it can be done by yourself easily using media queries.
Sometimes instructor goes way too fast through the code and it makes it quite difficult to follow it, you will need to rewind or slow the video down at times.

results.content: I took the course because I wanted to build an application like Slack. The course content is nice. At the end of the course you will be able to build an application like Slack but you will not learn to do it yourself. This course is very good if you are really good with react, redux, and semantic-ui react. If not then this will just feel like a monologue by the instructor since he will just walk you through and the things that he do while he do it. He does not explain why he do it. Don't get me wrong, the instructor is very knowledgeable with what he's saying but the thing is, this is a teaching platform and we are students and in the end we should be learning and not just copying.

results.content: Overall, a nice and entertaining course. It would be a 5 start if it had a bit more explanations. And I don't mean elementary stuff, but just a bit more in depth regarding certain areas, so that audience can now why you made your choice as such. Keep up the good work. P.S. yarn is the way to go with package management, as I lost a couple of hours trying to make things work with npm (which is used in course video) - until I stumbled upon the comment of yours which suggested it only later. So please make that more visible.

results.content:
Ultimately a pretty good tutorial but the instructor is sloppy. 
He will change how the code is laid out between videos, making it hard to get a bearing on where he is in the next. 
Also, he moves real fast and doesn't necessarily dive into why hes doing something. 
If you're real intermediate on React, this might be the video for you. 
Typically I watch these videos at 1.25 to 1.5 time, not this guy... he moves REAL fast.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Hour # 3 in this tutorial - I'm sure the instructor is a nice guy and its obvious he knows what hes doing, but hes terrible at explaining what hes doing...

results.content:
First, the instructor knows his stuff and his code is well written.

But, that is the issue.  You're really just watching him code. There are no real explanations of the "why".  

The course could be vastly improved with the some explanationary slides.  Maybe diagram the design of a section before you start coding it or cover a concept (e.g Firebase:  setup, how interaction with the  database works [it is different], setting up permission).  The break points between videos is generally sufficiently defined that it would be pretty easy to add these.

I'm at about 25% through the course as I write the review and really debating if I want to finish (watch him code and hope to pick something up) or return the course.
results.content_html:

Project is overall really good and Reed is a really good teacher, explaining almost everything we need to know about the methods used in this course.

The only problem is that there is a really huge amount of people on this course, and Reed can't answer everyone's questions. It isn't his fault to be honest but mind this if you consider buying this lesson. 

This is not a beginner course, if you don't know what you're doing and don't know how to solve problems by yourself, you should know there is a good chance that the question that you ask to Reed is not going to  be answered.

results.content: Excellent to learn.
results.content_html: Excellent to learn.

results.content:
I went into this wanting to see a real world application be built with the three technologies: React, Redux, and Firebase. This instructor fulfilled that expectation and covers many edge cases to ensure the app could be used and secured without any more work needed. In inclusion of staring, notifications, and the typing animation are great polish!

With that said, this is not a course for people actually wanting to learn these technologies through actual instruction, and definitely not for beginners. The instructor goes fast (constantly typing, rarely reflecting on the progress) and there's little explanation. I mean, he does comment on his coding process, provides example document structure for each firebase ref, and does throw out a few bits of info, but it's 95% a code-along (where you frequently have to pause to keep up).

If you want to learn React and Redux, you'll need to find another course. If you don't understand NoSQL datastores or databases in general, you might want to read on that first.

BUT if you know the tech, want more experience building an actual app in React/Redux, and want to see Firebase in action, then this course is great! The speed (Apple TV app doesn't have speed change) and the "just copy me" vibe is why I took off a star.
results.content_html:
I went into this wanting to see a real world application be built with the three technologies: React, Redux, and Firebase. This instructor fulfilled that expectation and covers many edge cases to ensure the app could be used and secured without any more work needed. In inclusion of staring, notifications, and the typing animation are great polish!

With that said, this is not a course for people actually wanting to learn these technologies through actual instruction, and definitely not for beginners. The instructor goes fast (constantly typing, rarely reflecting on the progress) and there's little explanation. I mean, he does comment on his coding process, provides example document structure for each firebase ref, and does throw out a few bits of info, but it's 95% a code-along (where you frequently have to pause to keep up).

If you want to learn React and Redux, you'll need to find another course. If you don't understand NoSQL datastores or databases in general, you might want to read on that first.

BUT if you know the tech, want more experience building an actual app in React/Redux, and want to see Firebase in action, then this course is great! The speed (Apple TV app doesn't have speed change) and the "just copy me" vibe is why I took off a star.

results.content: Great course, but very fast. If instructor slowed down a bit this would be perfect. And I don't mean in terms of speed, as in 2x'ing to fix. I'm referring to pausing for a second after typing a line of code, so that the user can easily pause to copy or code along. Changes are made and off the screen before instructor has even finished saying what he was about to type. I think stating okay, now we'll add the users... type the few lines, re-iterate what each line does, pause for 1 second then move to next task. Otherwise, app looks great and works great. Finding tutorials with apps that actually work and look great are rare, so thank you.
results.content_html: Great course, but very fast. If instructor slowed down a bit this would be perfect. And I don't mean in terms of speed, as in 2x'ing to fix. I'm referring to pausing for a second after typing a line of code, so that the user can easily pause to copy or code along. Changes are made and off the screen before instructor has even finished saying what he was about to type. I think stating okay, now we'll add the users... type the few lines, re-iterate what each line does, pause for 1 second then move to next task. Otherwise, app looks great and works great. Finding tutorials with apps that actually work and look great are rare, so thank you.

results.content: Was just looking for this kind of course. Swift-paced, Complete and Direct To-The Point. Helped me understand some core concepts of React and Firebase. I support this course for any "intermediate" users looking for complete app-building projects.
results.content_html: Was just looking for this kind of course. Swift-paced, Complete and Direct To-The Point. Helped me understand some core concepts of React and Firebase. I support this course for any "intermediate" users looking for complete app-building projects.

results.content: great course! It's clear and packed with tons of useful info, but not at all a course for beginners.  If you are beginner, get a beginning React and Redux course, practice it for a while, and then come back to this course.  He doesn't explain every little step, which is nice if you already know React/Redux. He assumes that you know React, which is why he categorizes his course as intermediate.  I don't understand why beginning level people think that they can jump right in with an intermediate course. You will get frustrated and leave him less than the 5 starts that it deserves, but that's because YOU didn't read the course type which clearly states that this is an intermediate course.  READ.  jeeze.   Thanks! This is a wonderful course and exceeded my expectations.
results.content_html: great course! It's clear and packed with tons of useful info, but not at all a course for beginners. results.content: Very big course for the hours of video provided. Main focus is on firebase realtime database and firebase storage with some regular react, redux and semantic ui. Some things are not explained in depth and you might need to look up some things on your own, so the course might not be as good for beginners, but I like the fast paced approach.

Some things are not explained in depth and you might need to look up some things on your own, so the course might not be as good for beginners, but I like the fast paced approach.

results.content: This is a fantastic course. I am developing a React application with a Firebase backend and this class is answering every question I had and more. Kudos to the instructor!

results.content:
This is not a course. This is a guy talking about some scripts he has been coding for a while.
Sure, you will end up with a nice repo after the course (if you manage to follow it) and if that's what you want it's ok. 
But if your purpose is learning then this will not be helpful. This guy does not explain anything he is doing, why he is doing it or how. How things work or how should be done. 
Don't misunderstand me: the guy is good at what he does, coding. But he is not a teacher at all.
Also, some parts of the code are outdated.

results.content:
Everything was going alright until lesson 31. The modal class does not work. I don't know what others have done to get pictures and files to upload to the chat / firebase, but I even tried copying his code directly and it just doesn't work. After hitting upload, it just returns to the chat.

EDIT:
After much research I found the error in the way we were accessing firebase storage URL. App is running at GIFmsg.com
results.content_html:
Everything was going alright until lesson 31. The modal class does not work. I don't know what others have done to get pictures and files to upload to the chat / firebase, but I even tried copying his code directly and it just doesn't work. After hitting upload, it just returns to the chat.

EDIT:
After much research I found the error in the way we were accessing firebase storage URL. App is running at GIFmsg.com

results.content: Explanations are unclear at times and holy moly this guy moves way too fast and skips over many things entirely. ONLY take this course after you have a solid understanding of React and THEN want to learn about the deployment process and some bells and whistles for full-fledged apps.

results.content:
The content here is really valuable, but as mentioned by other people the instructor really goes fast. I've a previous knowledge of React and sometimes I feel like he do the things not explaining exactly why he is doing that.
Imagine you as a totally newbie on React, than he says you import this here, than there you create a store and voila! What's store ? What's the purpose ? 
Anyway, as I mentioned I have a previous knowledge of React so for me is Ok, but if you are really beginner I think this might not be the best course for you.

results.content:
I have a mixed feeling about this course, part of the reason would be I'm using hooks to follow along with the course. The instructor's pace is a bit fast than I expected and some of the content did not explain well enough (e.g. At first, I have no idea what firebase.database().ref('info/connected') would do and he did not explain it). 
But overall, it's a 6.5/10 imo, I would recommend this course to anyone with an intermediate level with React and it would help a ton for understanding hooks if you decide to use hooks to follow this course.
I recommend check out https://github.com/CSFrequency/react-firebase-hooks if you try to use hooks.
results.content_html:
I have a mixed feeling about this course, part of the reason would be I'm using hooks to follow along with the course. The instructor's pace is a bit fast than I expected and some of the content did not explain well enough (e.g. At first, I have no idea what firebase.database().ref('info/connected') would do and he did not explain it).
But overall, it's a 6.5/10 imo, I would recommend this course to anyone with an intermediate level with React and it would help a ton for understanding hooks if you decide to use hooks to follow this course.
I recommend check out https://github.com/CSFrequency/react-firebase-hooks if you try to use hooks.

results.content: Best course I've taken on Udemy and best one for learning React.  Learning by building a real-world app makes all the difference.  I also really like the short length of the videos.  Building the app was done very iteratively which was cool.  I'd recommend this course for anyone who wants to get up-to-speed with React.
results.content_html: Best course I've taken on Udemy and best one for learning React. Learning by building a real-world app makes all the difference. I also really like the short length of the videos. Building the app was done very iteratively which was cool. I'd recommend this course for anyone who wants to get up-to-speed with React.

results.content: I find this course REALLY educational and a bit complex too. It looks like this was exactly what I needed to scale up my understanding and abilities as developer in general - especially functional programming! Further, in a few lectures I needed to check the docs and dive deeper... Unfortunately the instructor in some cases just speaks out the code that he writes, without really explaining anything. And lately (09/2020) he doesn't answer any questions in Q&A. But again, it's a great course! You'll learn how to think as a programmer!

results.content:
Asked him a really simple question both in personal and public channel. I don't think he even read the question sections, there is a lot of simple but useful question that he could answer.

The support is awful. Let me tell you my question what it was and how fast he could answer it. 

He has a schema in his mind that he tries to code and build in firebase, and I asked him if he could present his idea in a json file instead of just showing it in video. Like a file called.  `FinalSchema.json` which has the schema of the whole app.

It would literally take around 5 minutes and would be really useful.

response.content: I read and respond to every question as best as I can. I provide all of the code in this course in dedicated files. I asked for additional explanation about your request, but you haven't responded. It's inappropriate to give the entire course one star as a result and incorrect to say I ignore questions. This comment is an unfair and inaccurate representation of the course.

results.content: The course covers some really useful things, too bad the instructor does not really bother to explain them. He mostly just says what he does, but he never really says why and what is takeaway from that, how you could use it in your own app (e.g. as a beginner, i would definitely would have appreciated more information on the firebase functions). He also goes very fast and the app is not responsive. I didn't get an answer for my question in the Q&A either, so maybe the instructor does not monitor the course anymore. Other than that, it was good practice, but there are lots of places for improvement.
